qas.question: This causes the rock unit as a whole to become longer and thinner.
Stretched rocks that pinch into lenses are known by what word?
Where can the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon be seen in less than the length of a meter?

answers.text: within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt

qas.question: Rocks that are a depth where they are ductilely stretched are also often what?

answers.text: normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning
normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning

qas.question: What is another word for thinning rocks in French?

plausible_answers.text: a location within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt

qas.question: Where can lower rocks of the Grand Canyon be seen?
What happens to sediment layers that are also thinning?
What does extension do to sediment that is less than a meter long?

plausible_answers.text: drop rock units that are higher below those that are lower

qas.question: How does sediment make rock fall?
What places younger units above older units?
How long is the Maria Fold?
What was the stretched sequence in the Grand Canyon named?

context: Extension causes the rock units as a whole to become longer and thinner. This is primarily accomplished through normal faulting and through the ductile stretching and thinning. Normal faults drop rock units that are higher below those that are lower. This typically results in younger units being placed below older units. Stretching of units can result in their thinning; in fact, there is a location within the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon can be seen over a length of less than a meter. Rocks at the depth to be ductilely stretched are often also metamorphosed. These stretched rocks can also pinch into lenses, known as boudins, after the French word for "sausage", because of their visual similarity.
